title: Takeaways
text:
Project Report[a]


Step-by-step guide


Data Preparation


Datasets






OSM geofabrik (OpenStreetMap data as of 2022-11-03T21:21:23Z)


LTA Data Mall Bus Stop 






Data Cleaning


Removal of redundant roads


Some roads such as “bridleway” were removed. By opening the attribute table and viewing all the locations, we saw that bridleways were not in our areas of consideration, so we removed all occurrences of bridleway.











Viewing of all data in Excel








We realised that there was too much data to manipulate in GQIS. As such, we exported the attribute table to Excel.





This allowed us to create a pivot table to visualise the more dominant features.











We can see from the Pivot table made, that a large proportion of all the roads we analysed belong to the service, footway, and residential categories. We will conduct a deeper investigation on what these classes of roads mean in the Singaporean context, and how it will be relevant to our analysis











We compared this data to the Data Dictionary provided with the file. This allowed us to determine what the different features represented.





In order to determine which parts roads pedestrians can walk on we first visited the Singapore Legal Statutes:





We found that “jaywalking” was only an offence if done within 50m of a designated crossing area or over a dividing railing. As such, we needed to analyse the road classifications to find which roads would be suitable to cross informally (expected to include tracks and residential roads).










































































Encoding Road Data





We then created an excel sheet to classify the road types manually. 








We opened each layer next to Google Maps street view to see what representations of each class looked like:











Cycleway





We could see that cycleways are wide open spaces, well suited for both bicycles and pedestrians. We coded them accordingly. 





The speed limit we chose was 25km/h as that is the maximum speed limit for shared paths in Singapore under the 2018 Active Mobility Regulations.








We code the data accordingly:





Footway





For footways, we can see that they encompass normal pavements. Although they are narrower, we can say that they are suitable for bicycles. Based on the previously mentioned legislation, the maximum speed for footways is 10km/h as such, we will code the data accordingly.








One important factor to note is that not all pavements have been encoded into the analysis. 


The road on the left only appears as a ‘service’ road, even though it also has a pavement. As such, we can expect to code service roads as walkable.














Living street


According to the data dictionary, living streets are streets “where pedestrians have priority”. There weren’t many of these streets near the area of analysis, but the areas that did have living streets tended to be located near a lot of commercial activity, attracting many visitors. One such example, about 1.5km from Tanjong Rhu station is Muskat Street, outside Sultan Mosque. 





Since this area is dedicated as having “Pedestrian priority,” we treat it as a footpath and limit the bicycle speed to 10 km/h.

































































Motorway


The main motorway running through our area of analysis is the East Coast Parkway Expressway (ECP).





The ECP and all motorways are not suitable for bicycles as stated in the legal statutes. However, the expressway does have frequent underground crossings (pictured to right of street view). In this case, the crossing are coded as ‘footways’. 





To prevent bicycles from going on the expressway, we set the bikespeed to 0 km/h.


















































Motorway link


Since motorway links lead to motorways, they will be classified in the same way.





Path


It was not immediately obvious what the difference between a path and a footpath was, however after analysing the area outside Singlap station, it was clear that an example of a path in the local context is a dirt path, without any proper concrete paving. 





Due to their narrow width, we can classify paths similarly to how we did footpaths.



































Pedestrian


Roads coded as ‘pedestrian’ are frequently located right outside the coming Marine Parade MRT Station. They tend to be pedestrianised roads and are crowded with local shops.





From the google maps street view, we see that while there is heavy bicycle usage, the pathways can be quite narrow. As such, they are classified similarly to footpaths.















































Primary


The most prominent primary road is Marine Parade Road. It is a bustling street with moderate vehicle traffic. 





From the analysis, we can see that large portions of the road are more than 50 metres from a crossing location. As such, jaywalking is permitted and the road can be classified as crossable. We also see that there are footpaths located parallel to the road, so we will not classify the road as walkable. Since the traffic is slow-moving, we classify “heavy vehicles” as false. Since bicycles are permitted on the road, we say that the bike speed is 30 km/h.






































Primary link


One example of a Primary link class road is a road connector (or a fork) that connects Mountbatten Road to the Tanjong Katong Road South. This road class consists of roads that link the Primary class roads to other Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary class roads.








From the GoogleMap view, we can see that this road class is the same in nature as the Primary road class, we will hence encode this class the same way Primary roads are encoded. To support this decision, we can also see that Primary link roads usually have a zebra road crossing, making it crossable. 


























Residential


Residential Roads consist of roads that connect residential areas, like affordable public housing (HDBs) and landed properties, much like the Kee Sun Avenue residential area seen in the screenshot below. 











These roads usually invite less traffic because they connect residential areas, where busy activities like commercial or entertainment do not usually happen. Most traffic would justly be transport activities to and from people’s living spaces, which probably will not happen more than a few times a day. 





Despite being regular asphalt roads, we will hereby classify them as walkable and crossable. Since these roads are generally less busy and have fewer heavy vehicles, cyclers will also have a speed of 30km/h.








Secondary


Secondary roads are generally smaller roads that connect to smaller towns. In the case of the screenshot below, Tanjong Katong Road South had branched off from the Primary road of Mountbatten road. This allows commuters to access deeper, less busy areas like residential areas, or transfer from one Primary road to another major road, like another Primary road or a Motorway.








As we can see from the screenshot above, large portions of the road are more than 50 metres from a crossing location, much like Primary roads. As such, jaywalking is permitted and Secondary roads will hereby be classified as crossable. Since this is a generally busy road, we will also not classify the road as walkable. Similarly, since the traffic can be fast moving, we classify “heavy vehicles” as true. Since bicycles are permitted on the road, we say that the bike speed is 30 km/h.








Secondary link


Similar to Primary link roads, Secondary link roads connect Secondary roads to other classes of roads, like Primary Roads, other Secondary roads, or in the case of the screenshot below, where East Coast Road branches into Telok Kurau Road, it connects to a Tertiary Road. 











Since Secondary link roads are extensions to Secondary roads and are similar to Primary link roads whereby they usually consist of a zebra crossing for pedestrians. As such, we will classify them as non-walkable, crossable, with heavy vehicular traffic, and with a bike speed of 30km/h. 


























Service


Service Roads consist of smaller and shorter roads that connect larger roads like Primary Roads, Secondary Roads, and Tertiary Roads to public infrastructure like petrol stations, and parking spaces, or are roads that are within a certain compound, like a school, or in the case of the screenshot below, a residential compound, Marine Terrace Breeze, south of the Marine Terrace Station.











Since these roads do not have heavy vehicular traffic and are usually quiet, we will classify these roads as walkable and crossable. We will also set the maximum bicycle speed as 15 km/h in line with the road speed limit for all vehicles.

















Steps


Steps Roads consist of a flight of steps that pedestrians have access to via walkways or footways. One common occurrence of steps is the flight of steps leading up to overhead bridges, as shown in the screenshot below. 











Since these “roads” are non-vehicular and are for people, we hence will classify them as walkable, crossable, without heavy vehicular traffic. Since cyclist will be able to carry their bikes over the steps, they will travel at the 4 km/h walking speed. As such, bike speed is set to 4.














Tertiary


Tertiary Roads are similar to Secondary Roads, whereby it is a lower class of roads that connect to even smaller roads like Service Roads. It also acts as a connector between higher classes of roads like Primary Roads and, in the case as seen in the screenshot below, Bayshore Road, which connects to a Secondary Road, Upper East Coast Road to the Motorway link towards East Coast Parkway. 











Since these roads are generally busy with heavy vehicular traffic, especially in the case of Bayshore Road, we will not classify them as walkable. However, similarly to Primary and Secondary Roads, we will still classify them as crossable, and set the maximum biking speed to 30km/h.











Tertiary link


Tertiary link roads are roads that branch off Tertiary roads, similar to Primary and Secondary link roads. They consist of regular asphalt roads that connect Tertiary roads to lower classes or smaller roads like Residential roads and Service roads.











Since these roads are the same in nature as Tertiary roads, we will encode them the same way - as non-walkable, crossable, with heavy vehicular traffic, and with a maximum biking speed of 30km/h.




















Track (Track grade1, 2, 3, 4 and 5)


Track Roads (including grades one through five) are generally paved or unpaved roads that are used in natural environments like nature reserves and parks. However, most of the Track roads in and even outside our work area (along the TEL Stage 4 stations) are usually behind a gate, indicating that these roads are off-limits by the common citizen. The screenshots below show examples of these roads. 











Hence, we will categorise these roads as unwalkable, uncrossable, without any heavy vehicular traffic and a max biking speed of 0 km/h.





















Trunk


Trunk Roads are similar to Motorway Roads, in which they carry very heavy and high-speed traffic over long distances. In the screenshot below, Still Road South, a Trunk Road, is a semi-expressway entrance ramp to the Outer Ring Road System. 











Since trunk roads are generally expressways that travel a long distance and have very heavy and high-speed traffic, it would would be extremely difficult and unsafe for pedestrian and cyclists to travel using them. Additionally, people (without heavy vehicles) and cyclists are, by law, barred from expressways. We will thus classify them as unwalkable, uncrossable, with heavy vehicular traffic and 0 km/h for cyclists. 





The screenshot below shows the Singapore Legal Statutes prohibiting and persons on enter or staying on an expressway on foot:








The screenshot below shows the Land Transport Authority issuing a warning about the prohibition of cyclists on expressways:





















Trunk Link


Similar to Trunk Roads, Trunk Link roads are linking roads that link Trunk Roads to other Trunk Roads, or roads with a lower class like Primary, Secondary, or Tertiary Roads. In the screenshot below, we can see the Trunk Link Road connecting Still Road South to the East Coast Park Service Road.











As previously mentioned, pedestrians and cyclists are not allowed on Trunk Roads. Since Trunk Link Roads are meant for linking Trunk Roads to other roads, we will classify this road as unwalkable, uncrossable, with heavy vehicular traffic and 0 km/h for cyclists. 



































Unclassified


Unclassified roads are roads that are general-use roads that do not usually carry heavy traffic. The screenshot below shows an example of an Unclassified Road, the East Coast Park Service Road, that allows vehicles to travel along the the East Coast Park area. 








Since these roads are generally less busy, we will classify them as walkable, crossable, without heavy vehicular traffic, and with a cycling speed of 30km/h.












































Unknown


Unknown Roads are road types that are unknown, unlabelled, or unclassified. There is only one road in Singapore that is classified as such, but it is beyond our work area. For informational purposes, the screenshot below shows a concrete pavement branching off of Kim Keat Avenue, near the Bradell-Toa Payoh area, to a concrete futsal court. 








For completion’s sake, we will classify Unknown Roads as unwalkable, uncrossable, without heavy vehicular traffic and a maximum biking speed of 0km/h. 











Blank


Road data that is classified as Blank do not have any data on the type of road. In our dataset, there are 0 Blank data. For completion’s sake, we will classify Blank Roads as unwalkable, uncrossable, without heavy vehicular traffic and a maximum biking speed of 0km/h. 














QGIS Integration (for Road Data)


Converting Encoded data to SQL


The coded data needed to be converted to SQL.





By using excel string concatenation, we programmatically created the SQL code and filled it across all cells.





We then ran the resulting code in the field calculator function of QGIS. 





We carefully look through the preview section to ensure that the correct code has been assigned. 








By carefully inspecting the resulting table, we can see that the data is encoded as desired.





We repeat the steps for the remaining three columns.








Exporting the layers in QGIS





In order to access just the walkable paths, we select walkable features and add them to a layer named ‘walkable’.











As such, we can create layers for each of the respective analysis:



































QNEAT 3 analysis


When filling out the QNEAT form, we realised that there was no function to indicate that roads are crossable and not, as such we did analysis on the map to find out the average distance between crossable and non-crossable roads. 





We found that crossable roads tended to be less than 15 metres apart.





While non-crossable roads (such as expressways) were over 20 metres apart.


As such, we set the topological tolerance for our study at 15 meres.











Then we can set up the batch process with the above parameters with topological tolerance of 0 metres.


And do another analysis with topological tolerance of 15 metres.








Once the result of both analysis has been computed, we can see that there is a slight problem with the rendering — there are some lines where there shouldn’t be — especially for the smaller analysis areas.








To do this, we tried increasing the raster cell size from 10 to 100.











Doing so resulted in the error margin being reduced. However there were still some erroneous data points. As shown:












When changing the cell size to 5, we get the following result:





After carefully exporting and considering over 20 layers of ise-areas, we decided that using an iso-area with a tolerance of 15 and cell size of 120 would be ideal for our analysis.





By changing the symbology, we can better see the variation for each of the transportation modes. 






























































Calculating the demand for TEL4 stations


Household demand


After creating the 1km dissolved buffer zone from the TEL4 stations, we searched for the number of households living in each condominium or apartment complex. However, there is insufficient information on the internet. Thus, we assume that the number of households is equivalent to the number of units in the apartment complex within the buffer zone.





For HDB apartment complexes, data on the total number of units per HDB block belonging to an estate can be found. However, for condominiums, only data on total number of units for the whole condominium can be found. We then decided to standardise by calculating the number of units for the whole estate for HDBs, and the number of units for the whole condominium. The same thing applies to landed properties.





Before we start, let’s clip the dissolved buffer zone layer with the land use layer as such.





HDB apartments








From the picture above, Marine Terrace Haven estate comprises Blocks 51 to 59. We then individually searched for the number of HDB units in the first block, eg. Block 51 has 270 units as shown.











The left column refers to the block number while the right column refers to the total number of units. Using basic Excel functions, there are a total of 1595 units in Marine Terrace Haven estate.


Condominiums


As for the number of units in a condominium, the data is readily available. A simple Google search will tell you how many units without having to do extra calculations. For example, let’s search on the number of units in Costa Rhu Condominium. 








From the above picture, we can see that there are 737 units in Costa Rhu condominium. We manually key in this data under the newly created field ‘Households’.


Landed properties


Before we start, similar to what we did with the land use layer, clip the buildings layer together with the dissolved buffer zone.





Since it is tougher to identify the number of units in the region, we will use the ‘select feature by freehand’.





While the Land Use layer is below the Buildings layer on the browser panel, use the tool above and drag along the boundary of the land use layer as shown.








You may now open the attribute table to look at how many buildings you have selected.





Some of the landed properties are semi-detached houses. Take this value and multiply it by 2 to account for them. We will repeat this process until we have covered all the landed properties found in our  land use layer.





After manually entering the households for all the residential buildings in the land use layer, click on the ‘Select by Expression’ icon and key in the following code:








Push your selected features to the top by clicking on the following icon below. Your attribute table should look like this.








Troubleshooting the limitations


However, you will notice that some of the HDBs, condominiums, landed properties and shophouses are still not accounted for in the OSM Landuse layer as shown below.








Thus, in order to account for the other residential buildings, we will have to merge the buildings layer with the land use layer. 





After merging the vector layers, look at the regions without the land use layer and compare it with the Google Maps. An example is shown in the picture below.








Next, compare the same area with Google Maps. You will notice that some of the buildings are HDB flats. 








As such, similar to how you find the number of units per HDB block in the OSM Land Use layer earlier, repeat the same steps with Upper East Coast Road, as shown in the above picture.





Repeat the same steps until you have covered all the empty spots that the Land Use layer did not cover.





Once done, open the Attribute Table of the Merged OSM layer. Click on the ‘Select by Expression’ icon, and key in the following SQL expression.








Then click on the  icon.





On your Attribute Table dialog window, the heading should look like this.








From your Layers panel, right click on the merged OSM layers > Export > Save Selected Features As








Then save your household demand data into your SG Geopackage, named ‘residential_data’. This will remove all the null data in your merged OSM layer. 





Calculating Total Household Demand


On your main QGIS window, click on Database > DB Manager








Once your DB Manager dialog window opens, on the left panel, click on Virtual Layers > Project Layers > residential_data layer to make the layer active.


Then click on the icon above.





Type the following SQL expression.





Then click on the Execute button below the SQL text box.





The query should return the sum of Household units.





The value above is our estimation for the total number of households that are able to access the TEL Stage 4 MRT stations within the 1km buffer. Since the opening of TEL Stage 3, the government proposed that 180,000 households will be able to access the existing TEL stations from Woodlands North to Gardens by the Bay station. When TEL Stage 4 finally opens in 2024, we will have at least 234,000 households with access to the TEL stations from Woodlands North to Bayshore station. 
























































Point-of-Interest (POI) demand





Points of Interest consist of any amenities, places, services or centres that people travel to.  This might include ATMs, schools, parks, swimming pools, shopping malls or cemeteries. In order to obtain the demand data for these points of interest in our catchment areas, we first clip the POIs that are in our catchment area.











In order to prevent duplication of demand data, we will remove any polygon that are inside another larger polygon - in which the larger polygon will subsume the smaller polygons it contains. For example, we can see that in the screenshot below, there is a smaller polygon contained in the East Coast Park Zone B polygon. We will assume that people travelling to East Coast Park Zone B will be the same people who will visit the inner polygon, which is the Road Safety Community Park.








In the screenshot below, we selected the inner polygon and deleted it using the Select Features by Area or Single Click function to delete the polygon. 








After removing all the irrelevant polygons, we will begin classifying the POIs based on their approximate annual visitorship/demand using a csv file.











In our work area, two of the most prominent points of interest are East Coast Park, which attracts more than 7 million visitors per year (which we will hereby assume a conservative 7 million people), and National Stadium, which attracts more than 4.8 million visitors per year as of 2021. Since these two points are hotspots for visitors, we will separate them as another classification by modifying the fclass column in the attribute table.





East Coast Park


East Coast Park is not just a hub of various recreational activities, including cycling, skating, waterskiing, and fishing, but is also where a 15-kilometre-long beach sits. This makes East Coast Parks one of the most popular attractions among tourists and locals alike, with an estimated 7 million visitors per year as mentioned on the NParks website in the screenshot below.











Additionally, we will merge the polygons of all East Coast Park Zones into one East Coast Park polygon using the Edit Geometry function and merging the selected features.











We will thus record its annual visitorship of 7 million.











































































































National Stadium


The National Stadium is one of the prime spots in Singapore hosting large scale events like National Day Parade 2015 and countless concerts and sporting events. In the screenshot of a Straits Times below, we can observe that the National Stadium, also known as the Sports Hub, has attracted 4.8 million visitors in the year of 2021.











We will thus record its annual visitorship of 4.8 million.




































































School


Schools are categorized as educational institutions or schools that are below the level of Junior Colleges. This includes Kindergartens, Primary and Secondary Schools. The screenshot below shows an example of a secondary school, St Patrick’s School, in the Marrine Terrace area.











Since each category (primary, secondary and kindergarten) has a large variance of number of students, we will separate them into 3 subcategories of the same name. We will also modify the fclass of these rows by researching their name to their level. Other schools that do not fit into the 3 subcategories will be classified as other schools.


Primary Schools


Using the data from data.gov.sg, we find that there are a total of 165,547 students and 11,799 teachers from government-funded primary schools and a total of 67,103 students and 4,243 teachers from government-aided primary schools for the year 2020. This brings us to a total of 177,346 students and teachers from government-funded primary schools, and a total of 71,346 students and teachers from government-aided primary schools.





We also find that there are data including the number of primary schools in Singapore - for which there are 139 government-funded primary schools, and 41 government-aided primary schools for the year 2020.





We will then take the total average of the average number of students and teachers per government-funded school and the average number of students and teachers per government-aided school.





Average number of students and teachers per government-funded school = 177,346 // 139 = 1275





Average number of students and teachers per government-aided school = 71,346 // 41 = 1740


Total average number of students and teachers per primary school in Singapore = (1275 + 1740) // 2 = 1507





We will multiply then 1507 to the number of schooldays (200) to calculate an approximate annual demand = 1507 * 200 = 301400





We will thus record the demand for primary schools as 301,400.


Secondary Schools


Using the data from data.gov.sg, we find that there are a total of 162,071 students and 13,669 teachers from secondary schools across all types for the year 2020. This brings us to a total of 175,740 students and teachers from secondary schools. We also find that there are data including the number of secondaryschools in Singapore - for which there are 136 secondary schools.





We will then take the average number of students and teachers per secondary school.





Average number of students and teachers per secondary school = 175,740 / 136 = 1292





We will multiply then 1292 to the number of schooldays (200) to calculate an approximate annual demand = 1292 * 200 = 258,400





We will thus record the demand for secondary schools as 258,400.


Kindergartens


To obtain the average number of students in kindergartens, we will use the aggregate data from data.gov.sg using information from MOE kindergartens. 





Using data.gov.sg, we find that there are a total of 7517 enrolled students into MOE kindergarten in 2022. We can also observe that there are 43 MOE kindergartens in Singapore as of 2022 from the MOE website from the screenshot below.








We will find an average of kindergarten students per kindergarten for our data preparation. 





7517 // 43 = 174





We will multiply then 174 to the number of schooldays (200) to calculate an approximate annual demand = 174 * 200 = 34,800





We will thus record the demand for kindergartens as  34,800.


Other Schools


The Other Schools category consists of the entires People’s Up, Singapore Hokkien Huay Kuan, and St Andrew’s Autism School. Since these institutions do not fit any of the three subcategories above, we will assume an average of the subcategories above and use it for this category of school.





Average number of students in Other School = (174 + 1507 + 1292) // 3 = 991.





We will multiply then 991 to the number of schooldays (200) to calculate an approximate annual demand = 174 * 200 = 182,200





We will thus record the demand for Other Schools as 182,200.


College


Colleges consist of Junior Colleges (JCs). We will define JCs strictly to non-mixed levels schools for simplicity’s sake. We will use data.gov.sg data to obtain the average number of students and teachers in a JC as a basis of demand. From the data.gov.sg data, we can observe that there are 15,373 students, 1,534 teachers, 22 vice principals, 11 principals, and 274 education partners for the year 2020. This brings us up to total of 17,214 people. 





We assume that each JC has one principal, which means that for the year 2020, there are 11 JCs. We will then have to find the average number of people in each JC by dividing the number of people over the number of JCs.





Average number of people in a JC = 17214 // 11 = 1564








We will multiply then 1564 to the number of schooldays (200) to calculate an approximate annual demand = 1564 * 200 = 312,800





We will thus record the demand for Other Schools as 312,800.





























Park


Parks are either manmade or natural environments that houses plants, greenery for human enjoyment and recreation. As mentioned above, East Coast Park is an example. Another example is Katong Park, as seen in the screenshot below.











To obtain park visitorship information, we will use our data from East Coast Park as a basis for our demand for the other parks. We will take the total annual visitorship divided by the total area of East Coast Park to obtain an average annual visitor demand to park per unit area. We will then extrapolate each park using the average value.





Total annual visitorship (East Coast Park) = 7,000,000


Total area (East Coast Park) = 1734364.16 square metres





Average annual visitorship (Park) = 7,000,000 // 1734364.16 = 4 visitor per square metre





In the case of Katong Park, which has an area of 28999.43 square metres, will have an approximate visitorship of 115,997 (28999.43 * 4).





We will thus record the demand for parks as 4 visitor per square metre





























Swimming Pool


To approximate the number of visitors to swimming pools, we will use annual swimming pool attendance obtained from Statista (2.53 million visitors), and divide it by the number of public swimming pools. There are an average of about 3 swimming pools per swimming complex. Since there are 26 public swimming complexes in Singapore, we will multiply 26 with 3 to get 78, the number of public pools in Singapore. We will then divide the number of visitors by 78 to obtain the number of visitors for one public swimming pool.





2.53 million / 78 = 32,435 annual visitors per public swimming pool





We will thus record the annual demand for one swimming pool as 32,435 visitors. 


Hospital


There is a single instance of “Hospital” in work area. In the screenshot of our attribute table below, we can see that the single instance is Econ Medicare, a nursing home facility. 











From Singstat, we can observe that there are currently 16,604 residents in Old Folks’ Home, which is another term for nursing homes. From Data.gov.sg, we can observe that there are 87 Old Folk’s Homes (inclusive of Nursing Homes and Inpatient Palliative Care Homes).





To find the average number of residents in Old Folks’ Home, we will divide he number of residents by the number of homes. 





Average number of residents in Old Folks’ Home = 16,604 / 87 = 190





To find the annual visitorship, we assume that each resident has at least one visitor every weeks, conservatively speaking. This means that each year, each resident will be visited at least 52 times. We will then multiply the number of visitation by the average number of residents in Old Folks’ Home. 





Average annual visitorship to Old Folks’ Home = 190 * 52= 9880





We will thus record the annual demand for one swimming pool as 9,880 visitors. 

















Graveyard


To approximate the annual visitorship to graveyards, we will estimate the number of graves in these graveyards according to their areas. We will do this by obtaining available information on the number of graves per square meter from existing cemeteries - in particular, Choa Chu Kang Cemetary.





We will take reference to a Straits Time article, which mentions a scaling-down of the Choa Chu Kang Cemetery from 318 hectares to 200 hectares - with a loss of some 80,500 graves. In this case, we will assume that 118 hectares would be able to contain 80,500 graves, and that subsequently, one hectare would be able to contain 682 graves.





Since 1 hectare is equivalent to 10,000 square metres, we can safely assume that for every 10,000 square meters, there will be 682 graves.





We will also assume, conservatively, that each grave will be visited once per year. 





In this case, similar to our Park classification, we will assume that for every 1 square metres, 0.0682 visitors will visit each year. 





We will thus record the annual demand for parks as 0.0682 visitors per square metre





Theatre


With only one instance of Theatre, which points to the Kallang Theatre, a Performing Arts venue, we will thus assume that large-scale events will be held there at least twice a month. With a size of 1,744 seats, we will round up the visitorship to 1,800 for performers, tech, and administrative personnel. Assuming 1,800 people visit the theatre twice a month, the annual visitorship will be:





1800 x 26 = 46800 visitors





We will thus record the annual demand for Theatre as 46,800 visitors





Others





Due to insufficient online data or negligible visitorship, we will opt out of any POI from our OSM layer with the following tags:



Pub


Hotel


Pitch


Playground


Community Centre


Restaurant


Food Court


Museum


Library


Fast Food


Shelter


Car Wash


Arts Centre


Mall


Bank


Police


Convenience


Water Works


Track


Observation Tower


Monument


Castle























Preliminary Analysis


These are the following datasets that we have used:



OpenStreetMaps Layers from GeoFabrik


Bus stop data from LTA Data Mall






After downloading the data from relevant websites, we imported the data into QGIS to begin our preliminary analysis. 





We did our first preliminary analysis using a 1km buffer zone. For this layer (TELS4_BUFFER_ZONE_SUBZONE), we:



Created the following fields:




BUFF_SZ_AREA




$area




SZ_DENSITY 




"SG — 2022_POP_DATA_Total_Population"   /  "MP19_SUBZONE_FULL_SZ_AREA"




BUFF_NAIVE




  "SZ_DENSITY"  *  "BUFF_SZ_AREA" 






We organized the data afterwards:



Saved TELS4_BUFFER_ZONE_SUBZONE as TEL_CIRC_RES_SZ (TEL, circular buffer, residential based on subzone data) with joined layers to do more manipulation


Classified segment subzones by population










Used the Filter option to show a buffer for just a single station, if not the buffers overlap and you can’t see the data underneath










We can now see just one MRT catchment.






We then labelled the MRT stations:





Next, we create a label for each MRT station. I chose to do it on the TELS4_MRT_STATION_CENTROID layer but could change it to another layer if we wanted.









Open the expression editor and make the value: "Name" + ' Station’ so that we see “Station” after each name 






We also created a print layout for our preliminary analysis:





We made a default title project style to reduce double work





Made a default plan view:








We repeated the print layouts for the remaining train stations:


















































Network Analysis


Creating exit points for each station


For every MRT station, we need to analyse the exact station exits.


To do this, we create a temporary scratch layer.











Set the layer name to mrt_name_exits and the geometry type to point.


Click OK.





Using the Add Point Feature  add points where the expected exit locations are.





Save the layer to a geopackage to make it permenant.












































Creation of Network Analysis layer





Once we have the layer, we can create the Iso-Area as Polygon.





In the resulting dialogue box, select Run as Batch Process.


Fill the form with the following attributes:














Click Run once the form has been filled.





The resulting screen should look something like this











Now, we repeat the steps for the remaining 6 stations.















Bus Stop Data


Importing bus stop data


Bus stop usage is an on demand data set. We had to do a lot of research on how to access this data as we did not have any prior experience getting GIS data by an API. 





Thankfully, LTA provided data on how to access file using the API. 








We found that the data must be called with an API request. This was done using two methods:


Firstly, using Postman we attempted to download the file:


​​





This only allowed us to access data from one month, in an attempt to access the data from earlier months, we decided to access the file programmatically. 








This resulted in the exact same file.





As such, we just took the usage data as is.





Data processing


We needed to code the bus stops to physical locations. This was done with the BusStop layer on data.gov.sg.





Both data sets contained the bus stop number field, which we could use as a primary key. The only discrepancy was that the usage data left 4 digit bus stop numbers as 4 digits, while the bus stop location data appended a 0 to the start to make all the numbers 5 digits.





Type the following code to append a ‘0’ to strings with a 4 digit bus stop. 





By checking the file we can see that our code appears to work:








To ensure that all the codes are 5 digits long, we can create an extra formula to check the length of all the adjusted code to ensure that they are indeed 5 digits long.





All the new codes are indeed appropriately coded to 5 digits. We can now move on to the next step of amalgamating data at an annual level.





First, we create a pivot table with the required data:








As such, we have the data at daily level. We now need to convert this to an annual level.








The number of days in a year (after considering PHs) is calculated as follows:








By summing the number of days on weekends and PH, we can derive the total number of days for each constant.

















We then multiply the given number by the number of that day type in a year.


By filling down all 15,156 rows, we can see that the formula appears to still apply.











Upon further inspection, we can see that there are some bus stops that only run on weekends, the formula failed for these instances. However, since there are not many, we can recode them manually.














After the long and tedious process, we have clean data!


We convert this clean data to a pivot table to aggregate the tap data.











We can then convert this clean data into a normal table to round the values to an integer.

















Merging bus stop usage data with geospatial data


On the BusStop properties, go to Joins, Add Joins and fill out the details as follows:








This allowed us to successfully code 5045 entries! A 98% success rate, which is more than enough for our analysis.








Since the max value is less than the limitation of int 32, we can use INT32 as our data type.











Symbolisation


Once the data has been converted to an integer, we can apply symbolisation to the points. 








Choose Graduated from the drop down menu in the symbolisation pane.





For the value, select the newly created, ANNUAL_OUT field.





Open the Symbol Settings pane.





Click the  icon to add a new marker.





For the newly created lower marker, set the fill colour to Lush Green to match Singapore’s buses. 





We use the Digital Colour Meter tool to ensure that the exact same colour is used:





From the tool, we can see that the exact desired value is 7CBE31.


We set this value to the fill colour for the Simple Marker earlier mentioned.








For the above marker, set the layer type to SVG Marker.








In the SVG Browser section search for Bus.





Choose the image of the bus in a circle.





For the method, choose Size.





The bus stops are classified as desired.





Click OK to save changes.





We can see that the buses have been successfully classified according to their volume.


Merging layers


For aggregate analysis, we should merge all the individual layers into one. 





Go to Vector > Data Management Tools > Merge Vector Layers








Select all the layers that end with _low.








Leave the rest of the parameters as default.





The merged layer is successfully created.





Next we click the pencil tool and manually delete all of the overlapping iso-areas:


As such, we have an attribute table where each station corresponds with one iso-area shape:





Next, we use the Field Calculator to add the sum of all tap in data to the table.





Our code is as follows:


aggregate(layer:='BusStop_93655a4c_70b8_4904_8799_bc26487cb098',


          aggregate:='sum',


          expression:="ANNUAL_OUT",


          filter:=contains(geometry(@parent), $geometry)


          )








We have successfully got the bus tap out data for each station.





We can now convert this to a bar graph, which we can make in QGIS using the DataPlotly plugin.





The resultant bar chart looks as follows. 








Since it is not ideal to make a bar graph in QGIS, we will instead use Pandas in a Jupyter notebook.





Since we’re doing so much we might as well analyse all the iso-areas!





Using the earlier learnt methods, merge all the layers to a single layer:





The new layer is successfully created.








Add a STATION field for organisation.


We then manually go through every shape to find which can be excluded from the analysis.












We then add the relevant bus tap in and out details to the shapes.








We now have all the data we need!


For better visualisation, we will use Pandas to analyse the data. As such, we need to export the data to a CSV.








This allows us to successfully view all the data in a csv file.









We can then import this data into a Pandas dataframe:









After renaming the columns, we get the following:





This allows us to generate the graphs in higher fidelity than what QGIS offers.



[a]The project report should focus on but not be limited to the followings:


A detailed discussion of the GIS analysis process and functions used.


A comprehensive discussion of the analysis results.


A collection of analytical maps (can be static or interactive web maps)

title: Project Intro
text:
Test
A report published by the Singapore Department of Statistics (2020) has shown an increase in ridership, travelling time and distance across all types of public transport in Singapore, possibly leading to increased traffic congestion or breakdowns of public transport systems. Accessible and effective public transportation is essential to enable the thriving economy of the urban-dense, fast-paced island nation. This is why good planning of mass public transport systems like the Mass Rapid Transport (MRT) system is so important. 
Most recently, the development of the Thomson East Coast Line (TEL) has been a crucial part of Singapore’s plan to enable 4 in every 5 households to live within a 10-minute walk of a train station [1]. There have also been plans to expand the islandwide cycling network to about 700km by 2030 [2]. Our team will measure, analyse, and evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed Stage 4 TEL stations and the implementation of a cycling path network in those areas. 

The seven Stage 4 TEL stations we will analyse are shown below.


In addition to its much later opening in 2027 [3], most residential areas near the Founders’ Memorial station are covered by buffer zones of the adjacent Tanjong Rhu MRT. We will thus exclude the TE22A Founders’ Memorial MRT station from our analysis.

Our analysis:

Initial Data Exploration and Analysis

Using OSM data (POIs and residential)
Population data
Buffer zones

Data Extraction

Aggregate demand from bus stop data
OSM Road data

Data Classification

Manual labelling of OSM road layers for network analysis

Creation of analysis layers

Network analysis layer (QNEAT’s Iso Areas) for each MRT station
Measuring demand from analysis






With improved cycling infrastructure such as bike lanes and bike parks, the value and accessibility of the MRT stations are increased significantly. We also note that with the extended reach of cycling expands over multiple MRT lines, which makes it possible for relevant authorities to consider investing in biking infrastructure, rather than MRT stations. 
We urge the relevant authorities to consider investing higher in biking infrastructure to encourage a transport system that is sustainable, active, and affordable.

About this site

title: Catching Thomson
text: In resource-scarce Singapore, the primary purpose of public transport is to serve residents with efficient forms of mass transportation. Our study goes beyond traditional catchment analysis methods which focus on pedestrian catchment and also consider cycling catchment. This is in line with the LTA 2040 “Walk, Cycle, Ride” Masterplan and the growing popularity of cycling globally. With an estimated public cost of $25 billion and an ever-increasing ridership, it is essential to critically evaluate the full benefits of stage 4 stations along the Thomson East Coast Line (TEL).

title: Catching Thomson
text:
Project Objective

To find out the extent to which the opening of TEL Stage 4 stations will increase accessibility for residences, or for visitors visiting the nearby places of interest
To make a comparative analysis of the implementation of TEL Stage 4 stations with the implementation of the cycling routes in the same region.
To identify the limitations of our scope and suggest recommendations for future works

title: Catching Thomson
text:
Data

OpenStreetMaps Data Layers from GeoFabrik

Road Layers
Building Layers
POI Layers

LTA Data Mall Bus Stop Data

title: Catching Thomson
text:
Scope of Work
Thomson East Coast Line Stage 4 Stations (with exception of Founders’ Memorial).
We carried out 2 methods of analysis, by using a circular buffer and network analysis.

Circular Buffer Approach
This is the simplest, yet the most naive method, to deduce the catchment areas. We created a circular 1 km buffer from each station, to find the number of residents in the buffer area, assuming residents are evenly distributed.


Network Analysis
The next approach is based on the network analysis method. Instead of assuming a naive 1 km buffer, our catchment varies between multiple modes of transport along physical pathways or roads. In this case, the modes of transport include cycling in heavy traffic, cycling without heavy traffic, and walking.
